conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graphs of objects A and B to determine if the difference in displacement is continuously increasing.
The image shows two velocity-time graphs, labeled as A and B, both parabolic with A having a higher peak velocity.
The velocity-time graph for object A is above that of object B, indicating A has a higher initial velocity.
As time progresses, both objects move along the line with positions determined by integrating their velocity functions.
The displacement of object A at time t is given by the area under its velocity curve up to that time.
The displacement of object B at time t is given by the area under its velocity curve up to that time.
The difference in displacement between A and B at any given time t is the difference between these two areas.
Since the velocity of A is higher than B, the area under A's curve will be greater at each time interval, indicating a consistently increasing difference in displacement.
The difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing over the time interval from 0 to t1.
Yes. The difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing over the time interval from 0 to t1.
